Let's build a small graph to illustrate the effect of $\tau$ on the graph.


```{r}
edge1 <- rbind(c(0,0),c(1,0))
edge2 <- rbind(c(0,0),c(0,1))
edge3 <- rbind(c(0,1),c(-1,1))
theta <- seq(from=pi,to=3*pi/2,length.out = 20)
edge4 <- cbind(sin(theta),1+ cos(theta))
edges = list(edge1, edge2, edge3, edge4)
```


```{r}
graph <- metric_graph$new(edges = edges)
graph$build_mesh(h = 0.01, continuous = TRUE)
edge_number <- graph$mesh$VtE
XY_graph <- graph$mesh$V
```

```{r, fig.cap = captioner("Edge directions.")}
graph$plot(direction = TRUE) + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(text = element_text(family = "Palatino"))
```


```{r}
sigma <- 1
range <- 0.5
nu <- 1.5

kappa <- sqrt(8*nu)/range
tau <-sqrt(gamma(nu) / (sigma^2 * kappa^(2*nu) * (4*pi)^(1/2) * gamma(nu + 1/2)))  #sigma = 1, d = 1
alpha <- nu + 1/2

op <- matern.operators(alpha = alpha, tau = tau, kappa = kappa,
                         parameterization = "spde",
                         m = 2, graph = graph) 


cov <- op$covariance_mesh()

est_sigma <- sqrt(Matrix::diag(cov))


normal_sample <- rnorm(dim(cov)[1])
R <- chol(cov)
u = t(R) %*% normal_sample

B.tau <- cbind(0, 1, 0, log(tau)*rep(1, length(normal_sample)), 0)
B.kappa <- cbind(0, 0, 1, 0, log(kappa)*rep(1, length(normal_sample)))
# Log-regression coefficients
theta <- c(0, 0, 1, 1) 
# Compute the operator
nonstat_op <- rSPDE::spde.matern.operators(graph = graph,
                                      B.tau = B.tau,
                                      B.kappa =  B.kappa,
                                      parameterization = "spde",
                                      theta = theta,
                                      alpha = alpha)$covariance_mesh()
nonstat_R <- chol(nonstat_op)
nonstat_u = t(nonstat_R) %*% normal_sample
```
